Package cmu.edu.andrew.spoonacular

Class Amount

java.lang.Object
cmu.edu.andrew.spoonacular.Amount
public final class Amount
extends java.lang.Object
An immutable quantity of an object with standard measurement units.

An Amount cannot be constructed; it is returned by the API for methods that require the amount of a certain object, like Ingredient::amount or Recipe::nutrients. The quantity of an Amount is represented as a double, while the measurement unit is an enum, Unit.

The class has two accessors: quantity() and unit(), a conversion method: convertUnit(), and a toString method. convertUnit() can be used to create a new amount with a different unit but with the same physical quantity as the old amount (e.g. 1000 grams will be converted to 1 kilogram). Sample Code:
Amount amnt1 = new Amount(10, GRAMS);
Amount amnt2 = amnt1.convertUnit(KILOGRAMS);
assertEquals(amnt1.quantity(), amnt2.quantity() * 1000);

See Also:
Amount.Unit

  • Method Details

    • quantity

      public double quantity()
      Returns the quantity of the amount.
      Returns:

    • unit

      public Amount.Unit unit()
      Returns the unit of the amount.

      the unit of the amount.

    • convertUnit

      public Amount convertUnit​(Amount.Unit newUnit)
      Converts the Amount to a different unit and returns a new Amount with the new unit. The quantity of the new Amount will represent the same amount of volume/weight as the original Amount. OnlyUnits that measure the same underlying physical property can be converted from one to the other:

      Volume Units: TABLESPOONS, TEASPOONS, CUPS, MILLILITERS, FLUID_OUNCES Weight Units: KILOGRAMS, GRAMS, MILLIGRAMS, MICROGRAMS, POUNDS, OUNCES Misc Units (these units cannot be converted to another unit): CALORIES, IU, COUNT

      Parameters:
      newUnit - The unit to be converted into
      Returns:
      a new Amount with the new unit. The quantity of the new Amount will represent the same amount of volume/weight as the original Amount.
      Throws:
      java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the Amount cannot be converted to the newUnit because it does not meet the specification as mentioned above.

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a String representation of an Amount. The form of the string is "{quantity} {unit}".
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      a String representation of an Amount.
